ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the beginning and fate of our universe and got an introduction to quantum physics. Basically how really really big and really really small things work. Not too much about how they all interconnect; I only realized it when doing the final presentation and listening to everybody else's. A lot of the final answers to questions were "we don't know", but that's not really a fault of the class and is mostly just a reality of how physics acts weirdly for really really big and really really small things.
Learned a lot about quantum physics and relativity; topics included the big bang, inflation, gravitational waves, and more. Overall, a pretty interesting selection of topics was covered!
Learning quantum physics as a non-major
I feel like I got a great understanding of the cutting edge of physics today.
Good summary of many topics in quantum physics. Gained pretty good understanding.

I learned much more about our universe and the cutting-edge scientific topics which are being debated. I gained more familiarity with scientific terms and writing and feel like I am able to engage with that kind of material more easily.

I have a working understanding of basic quantum physics and the origin of the Universe. I would be able to do further research on topics related to quantum physics and be able to understand them with some effort.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: the subject matter is interesting, and the final presentation was incredible.
Weaknesses: the lectures are mind-numbingly boring. They're mandatory, but it was just listening to a very boring, very confusing lecture for 90 minutes (she often stopped early). I don't know how I would have survived if the lectures were in person; over Zoom, I just had them play in the background as I did other work.

Strengths: The material was super interesting! I hadn't interacted with the course material in a while and it was cool getting everything explained. 
Weaknesses:  I think the fact that we learned about it from a non-mathematically rigorous course meant that we didn't really get a complete picture or understanding of the material. Sometimes it was quite difficult to discuss or explain the topics without the use of math. That being said, this is probably not a weakness if you're taking this course as humanities or social science major.

Strengths: Lecture format and asking questions
Weaknesses: Maybe more discussion between students

I think the only weakness of this course is that a lot of kids take it who arent interested in the subject material so they dont put in the effort to get what you can get out of the class. It then makes it less fun for everyone else. That might be because of zoom though.
I think its one of those courses that is hard to keep engaging over zoom. But incorporating more assignments that allow students to work together would be good!

This is a very interesting course which does a great job of introducing complicated topics in science to non-majors in an understandable way. There is plenty of time to ask questions and you are encouraged to think about stuff on your own as well.

Its an amazing class especially for those who arent math/physics majors and want a science credit. Its well organised with weekly homeworks being set right after class giving a full week to complete. Marking was always quick and with good feedback. I felt there were no weaknesses.

I think this course is very good at explaining the concepts well. Professor Caines brought a great energy to the classroom and was always ready to answer any questions we had. The readings were also interesting, although long at points. I do think the weekly reading responses could be graded on completion or something more forgiving than this semesters grading system trying to answer the questions perfectly became pretty stressful for me especially as we went deeper into the concepts, and rather than being excited by new ideas, I was scared that I wouldnt understand them and lose points on the homework (especially because we wouldnt have an opportunity to ask questions in class before we turned in homework.)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Awesome engagement compared to many other classes. I dont think there are any improvements necessary.
I thought the lecture worked pretty well over zoom. I also think the presentations at the end of the course were great! I cant think of a way to improve that aspect of the course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you want a science gut, take it. It's incredibly easy and you learn some cool things by the end. Be aware that in-person lectures in this class may be very boring, but I don't think there's an easier class on this campus.

I would recommend this course if you're a humanities or social science major. If you're interested in math or physics, this course is not for you. I personally thought the material was interesting and easy to understand, but that's probably because I've studied many of these subjects before.
Definitely, I think all students who are not into science should take it. It is an excellent class
Yes! I think its a great way to learn quantum physics if you are interested but arent a physics major or such.
Absolutely. It is a fascinating course and is a wonderful opportunity for non-science majors who want to learn more about these topics.
Absolutely! Its a great course, Professor Caines is great and very understanding to students needs. The workload is fine and its very interesting.
This was excellent course geared toward students with not much of a physics background. Professor Caines made the material very accessible!
Yes. Although the subject material seems daunting, the workload is actually very manageable and the class is incredibly interesting.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was called a seminar but was really a lecture.
n/a
N/a
Lecture and discussion
At some points the lecture was more like a seminar. There was a lot of student engagement!
